org.apache.juneau.transform

Class PojoTransform<N,T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.juneau.transform.Transform
      • org.apache.juneau.transform.PojoTransform<N,T>
  • Type Parameters:
    N - The normal form of the class.
    T - The transformed form of the class.
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BeanStringTransform, ByteArrayBase64Transform, CalendarLongTransform, CalendarMapTransform, CalendarTransform, DateLongTransform, DateMapTransform, DateTransform, EnumerationTransform, IteratorTransform, PojoTransform.NULL, ReaderTransform, Schema.BooleanOrSchemaArrayTransform, Schema.BooleanOrSchemaTransform, Schema.JsonTypeOrJsonTypeArrayTransform, Schema.SchemaOrSchemaArrayTransform, SurrogateTransform, XMLGregorianCalendarTransform

    public abstract class PojoTransform<N,T>
extends Transform
    Used to convert non-serializable objects to a serializable form.
    Description

    PojoTransforms are used to extend the functionality of the serializers and parsers to be able to handle POJOs that aren't automatically handled by the serializers or parsers. For example, JSON does not have a standard representation for rendering dates. By defining a special Date transform and associating it with a serializer and parser, you can convert a Date object to a String during serialization, and convert that String object back into a Date object during parsing.

    Object transforms MUST declare a public no-arg constructor so that the bean context can instantiate them.

    PojoTransforms are associated with instances of BeanContexts by passing the transform class to the CoreApi.addTransforms(Class...) method.
    When associated with a bean context, fields of the specified type will automatically be converted when the BeanMap.get(Object) or BeanMap.put(String, Object) methods are called.

    PojoTransforms have two parameters:

    1. <F> - The transformed representation of an object.
    2. <T> - The normal representation of an object.

    Serializers use object transforms to convert objects of type T into objects of type F, and on calls to BeanMap.get(Object).
    Parsers use object transforms to convert objects of type F into objects of type T, and on calls to BeanMap.put(String,Object).
    Transformed Class Type <T>

    The transformed object representation of an object must be an object type that the serializers can natively convert to JSON (or language-specific equivalent). The list of valid transformed types are as follows...

    • String
    • Number
    • Boolean
    • Collection containing anything on this list.
    • Map containing anything on this list.
    • A java bean with properties of anything on this list.
    • An array of anything on this list.
    Normal Class Type <N>

    The normal object representation of an object.

    One-way vs. Two-way Serialization

    Note that while there is a unified interface for handling transforming during both serialization and parsing, in many cases only one of the transform(Object) or normalize(Object, ClassMeta) methods will be defined because the transform is one-way. For example, a transform may be defined to convert an Iterator to a ObjectList, but it's not possible to untransform an Iterator. In that case, the generalize(Object} method would be implemented, but the narrow(ObjectMap) object would not, and the transform would be associated on the serializer, but not the parser. Also, you may choose to serialize objects like Dates to readable Strings, in which case it's not possible to reparse it back into a Date, since there is no way for the Parser to know it's a Date from just the JSON or XML text.

    Additional information
    See org.apache.juneau.transform for more information.
    Author:
    James Bognar (james.bognar@salesforce.com)

    • Method Detail

      • transform

        public T transform(N o)
            throws SerializeException
        If this transform is to be used to serialize non-serializable POJOs, it must implement this method.

        The object must be converted into one of the following serializable types:

        • String
        • Number
        • Boolean
        • Collection containing anything on this list.
        • Map containing anything on this list.
        • A java bean with properties of anything on this list.
        • An array of anything on this list.
        Parameters:
        o - The object to be transformed.
        Returns:
        The transformed object.
        Throws:
        SerializeException - If a problem occurred trying to convert the output.

      • normalize

        public N normalize(T f,
                   ClassMeta<?> hint)
            throws ParseException
        If this transform is to be used to reconstitute POJOs that aren't true Java beans, it must implement this method.
        Parameters:
        f - The transformed object.
        hint - If possible, the parser will try to tell you the object type being created. For example, on a serialized date, this may tell you that the object being created must be of type GregorianCalendar.
        This may be null if the parser cannot make this determination.
        Returns:
        The narrowed object.
        Throws:
        ParseException - If this method is not implemented.

      • getNormalClass

        public Class<N> getNormalClass()
        Returns the T class, the normalized form of the class.
        Returns:
        The normal form of this class.

      • getTransformedClass

        public Class<T> getTransformedClass()
        Returns the G class, the generialized form of the class.

        Subclasses must override this method if the generialized class is Object, meaning it can produce multiple generialized forms.

        Returns:
        The transformed form of this class.

      • getTransformedClassMeta

        public ClassMeta<T> getTransformedClassMeta()
        Returns the ClassMeta of the transformed class type. This value is cached for quick lookup.
        Returns:
        The ClassMeta of the transformed class type.

      • isNormalObject

        public boolean isNormalObject(Object o)
        Checks if the specified object is an instance of the normal class defined on this transform.
        Parameters:
        o - The object to check.
        Returns:
        true if the specified object is a subclass of the normal class defined on this transform. null always return false.

      • isTransformedObject

        public boolean isTransformedObject(Object o)
        Checks if the specified object is an instance of the transformed class defined on this transform.
        Parameters:
        o - The object to check.
        Returns:
        true if the specified object is a subclass of the transformed class defined on this transform. null always return false.
